questions.ocrQuestion:
In the phenomenon of the photoelectric, the ejected electrons are :
(a) most of the times relativistic
(b) most of the times non-relativistic
(c) always relativistic
(d) most of the times stationary
questions.onlyq_text: In the phenomenon of the photoelectric, the ejected electrons are :

questions.ocrQuestion:
The photoelectric threshold for a metal is \( 3000 \unicode{xC5} \). The kinetic energy of an electron ejected from it by radiation of wavelength \( 1200 \unicode{xC5} \) is
(a) \( 3.1 \mathrm{eV} \)
(b) \( 12.6 \mathrm{eV} \)
(c) \( 6.2 \mathrm{eV} \)
(d) \( 21.4 \mathrm{eV} \)

questions.ocrQuestion:
The photoelectric equation is derived under the assumption that
(a) electrons are associated with waves of wavelenght \( \lambda=\frac{h}{p} \), where \( p \) is the momentum
(b) light is emitted only when electrons jump between the orbits
(c) light is absorbed in quanta of energy \( E=h v \)
(d) light behaves like a wave
questions.onlyq_text: The photoelectric equation is derived under the assumption that

options.option: (a) electrons are associated with waves of wavelenght \( \lambda=\frac{h}{p} \), where \( p \) is the momentum
(b) light is emitted only when electrons jump between the orbits
(c) light is absorbed in quanta of energy \( E=h v \)

questions.subject: PHYSICS

questions.concept_html: Planck's constant \( \mathrm{h}=6.63 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{Js} \) or \( 4.14 \times 10^{-15} \mathrm{eVs} \)Planck's constant \( \hbar=1.05 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{Js} \) or \( 6.58 \times 10^{-16} \mathrm{eVs} \)Mass of an electron \( =9.1 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{~kg} \)Charge of electron \( e=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C} \)\( \mathrm{mc}^{2} \) for an electron \( =0.511 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{eV} \)\( \mathrm{hc}=1240 \mathrm{eV} \cdot \mathrm{nm} \)\( \mathrm{c}=3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)
questions.ocrQuestion:
Light described by the equation [
E=(90 \mathrm{~V} / \mathrm{m})\left[\sin \left(6.28 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\right) t\right.
\]\( \left.+\sin \left(12.56 \times 10^{15} s^{-1}\right) t\right] \) is incident on a metal surface. The work function of the metal is \( 2.0 \mathrm{eV} \). Maximum kinetic energy of the photoelectrons will be
(a) \( 2.14 \mathrm{eV} \)
(b) \( 4.28 \mathrm{eV} \)
(c) \( 6.28 \mathrm{eV} \)
(d) \( 12.56 \mathrm{eV} \)

questions.ocrQuestion:
A metal surface has work function equivalence to energy of wavelength of light \( 4500 \unicode{xC5} \). When a beam of light with \( \lambda=4000 \unicode{xC5} \) falls on it
(a) photoelectrons will not be emitted
(b) photoelectrons will be emitted with certain speeds
(c) photoelectrons will be emitted with zero speeds
(d) photoelectrons may or may not be emitted
questions.onlyq_text: A metal surface has work function equivalence to energy of wavelength of light \( 4500 \unicode{xC5} \). When a beam of light with \( \lambda=4000 \unicode{xC5} \) falls on it

options.option: (b) photoelectrons will be emitted with certain speeds
(c) photoelectrons will be emitted with zero speeds
(d) photoelectrons may or may not be emitted
